name: Cameroon
currentCrisisSummary:
Cameroon endures multiple severe crises rooted in the violent legacies of its **colonial construction**. The most acute is the armed conflict in the Anglophone regions, where **state repression** against demands for political and cultural rights has escalated into a brutal war. This conflict results directly from a hyper-centralised, authoritarian state modelâ€”inherited from **French colonial rule**â€”that has systematically dismantled Anglophone autonomy.

In the Far North, **state neglect** fuels insurgency. Both crises are sustained by a **political economy of elite enrichment** and **foreign corporate extraction** (oil, timber), perpetuating suffering and displacement.

colonialRoot.legacy:
Cameroon's fractures were engineered by its **partition after WWI**. Germany's colony was divided between France and Britain, administered under different **colonial philosophies** (French **assimilation** vs. British **indirect rule**).

At independence, 'reunification' was an absorption of the Anglophone territory into the Francophone state. The promised federal structure was abolished. This **centralisation** imposed a foreign system, creating a dynamic of **internal colonialism** that led to war.

historicalContext.title: Violent Decolonisation and Neo-Colonial Control
historicalContext.description: Independence was born in violence. France waged a brutal war against the **anti-colonial movement** (UPC), killing tens of thousands, then installed a compliant regime. This ensured French economic interests remained secure, establishing a durable **neo-colonial relationship** (*FranÃ§afrique*) defining the state's repressive character.

historicalContext.title: The Anglophone Problem and Forced Assimilation
historicalContext.description: The Anglophone crisis results from decades of **systematic marginalisation**. Abolishing federalism in 1972 initiated deliberate **assimilation**. Anglophone legal/educational systems were eroded, regions economically neglected. These policies aimed to break Anglophone identity and consolidate state power.

historicalContext.title: Neoliberal Austerity and Structural Adjustment
historicalContext.description: Following an economic crisis (late 1980s), Cameroon adopted **Structural Adjustment Programmes (SAPs)** mandated by the **IMF** and **World Bank**. These **neoliberal policies** enforced severe **austerity** (lay-offs, **privatisation**, cuts). **SAPs hollowed out the state**, worsened inequality, and devastated livelihoods, creating grievance forming the backdrop to the 2016 explosion.

historicalContext.title: Resource Extraction and Elite Enrichment
historicalContext.description: For decades, an elite used state power to control revenues from oil, timber, etc. This system, often facilitated by **foreign corporations**, entrenched **corruption**. The state manages **extractive contracts** rather than providing services. Underdevelopment results directly from a **political economy** concentrating wealth and marginalising the periphery.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: Severe human rights violations by all sides are documented, yet **international accountability** has failed. Key partners (France, US) prioritise 'stability', offering muted criticism while continuing support. This **impunity** emboldens perpetrators.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Est. 6,000 civilians killed (Anglophone crisis since 2017) due to **indiscriminate violence** by state forces and armed groups.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 4.7 million require aid due to breakdown caused by **conflict** and **state neglect**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Est. 2.6 million face acute hunger, primarily in regions destabilised by **conflict** and **economic marginalisation**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 1 million internally displaced (Anglophone crisis & Far North) by **state violence** and armed attacks.

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 87,000 Anglophones forced into refuge by **state repression** and conflict.

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Around 80% of health facilities in Anglophone regions non-functional due to **attacks** and insecurity.

humanitarianImpact.title: Education Disrupted
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 600,000 children denied education (Anglophone regions) due to **attacks on schools** and conflict.

timeline.event: **German Colonisation**: Germany declares the protectorate of Kamerun, initiating a period of brutal colonial exploitation. German companies establish vast plantations for rubber and cocoa, built on the violent expropriation of land and a system of extensive forced labour.

**WWI Conquest**: During the inter-imperialist conflict of World War I, British and French forces invade and conquer German Kamerun. The territory and its people are treated as spoils of a European war, setting the stage for its eventual partition.
**Colonial Partition**: The former German colony of Kamerun is divided under the Treaty of Versailles, creating French Cameroun and British Cameroons and embedding two different colonial systems.
**France's 'Hidden War'**: French forces wage a brutal counter-insurgency war to destroy the nationalist UPC movement, ensuring a pro-French, authoritarian government assumes power at independence.
**Reunification**: Following a UN-backed plebiscite, British Southern Cameroons joins the newly independent Republic of Cameroon, forming a two-state federation.

**Abolition of Federalism**: President Ahmadou Ahidjo holds a rigged referendum that abolishes the federal system, creating a unitary state and marking the beginning of the systematic erosion of Anglophone autonomy.
**Paul Biya Takes Power**: Biya becomes president, consolidating the centralised, authoritarian system and ruling for over four decades through a combination of patronage and repression.

**Structural Adjustment**: Hit by an economic crisis, the government accepts IMF/World Bank-mandated Structural Adjustment Programmes (SAPs). The resulting austerity measures, including public sector wage cuts and layoffs, devastate the economy and fuel popular discontent.

**Anglophone Protests Erupt**: Lawyers and teachers in the Anglophone regions lead peaceful protests against the imposition of French-speaking judges and teachers. The state responds with violent repression.

**Descent into War**: The state's brutal crackdown catalyses the formation of armed separatist groups. The escalating conflict becomes a full-blown civil war, inflicting devastating harm on civilians.

donate.description: A UK-based charity that partners with rural Cameroonian communities to fund and build small-scale, sustainable development projects like solar-powered water systems and health centres.
A community-based organisation providing education, healthcare, and welfare support to underprivileged and displaced children affected by the ongoing crises.

advocacy.title: End Foreign Military Support & Impunity
advocacy.description: Demand that foreign governments, especially France and the US, halt military assistance and security cooperation with Cameroonian state forces implicated in human rights abuses, and call for targeted international sanctions on government officials and separatist leaders responsible for atrocities and for obstructing a peaceful resolution to the Anglophone crisis.

advocacy.title: Support Mediated Dialogue
advocacy.description: Advocate for an inclusive, internationally-mediated dialogue to address the root causes of the Anglophone conflict, including constitutional reform and governance.

advocacy.title: Amplify Local Voices
advocacy.description: Support Cameroonian human rights defenders and civil society organisations documenting abuses and working towards a just and peaceful future.

advocacy.title: Investigate Corporate Complicity
advocacy.description: Urge investigations into the role of foreign corporations in resource extraction that fuels corruption and exacerbates regional inequalities.

reading.title: *Radical Nationalism in Cameroun: Social Origins of the U.P.C. Rebellion*
reading.description: Richard A. Joseph's study of the anti-colonial UPC movement and the social forces behind its rebellion against French rule.

reading.title: *On the Postcolony*
reading.description: By Achille Mbembe. A seminal theoretical work exploring power, violence, and subjectivity in post-colonial Africa, using Cameroon as a key example.
